title: How to Make a Simple One‐Direction Electric Toy Car

steps.title: Poke a tiny hole through the plastic bottle cap, small enough for the rod to fit in.
steps.content: Poke a tiny hole through the plastic bottle cap, small enough for the rod to fit in.

steps.title: Wrap the bottle cap edges with tape.
steps.content: Wrap the bottle cap edges with tape. Electrical tape is useful here since it provides a rubbery grip around the wheel.

steps.title: Repeat the process 3 more times to the get 3 more wheels.
steps.content: Repeat the process 3 more times to the get 3 more wheels.

steps.title: Take a straw and cut the ends so it’s shorter than 4 inches to cover the rod.
steps.content: Take a straw and cut the ends so it’s shorter than 4 inches to cover the rod. Insert the 4-inch rod into both wheels and make sure the rod is exposed at both ends.

steps.title: Glue the rod to the wheels.
steps.content: Glue the rod to the wheels. Let it dry.

steps.title: Insert a tiny gear to one side of the other exposed rod.
steps.content: Insert a tiny gear to one side of the other exposed rod. Glue the other 2 wheels to the rod, and let it dry. This will allow the motor to turn the rods thus spinning the wheels.

steps.title: Place 2 popsicle sticks next to each other.
steps.content: Place 2 popsicle sticks next to each other. Glue both rods to the sticks.

steps.title: Wait for the glue to dry.
steps.content: Wait for the glue to dry.

steps.title: Insert the tiny gear into the shaft of the DC motor.
steps.content: Insert the tiny gear into the shaft of the DC motor. The shaft is the thin rod of the motor.

steps.title: Flip the car upside down so the rods are facing up.
steps.content: Flip the car upside down so the rods are facing up. Align the gear of the motor to the gear of the rod perfectly so when one gear moves the other gear will move as well. Glue the motor and wait for it to dry.

steps.title: Familiarize yourself with the equipment.
steps.content: Familiarize yourself with the equipment. These steps will require you to have basic knowledge on how to solder. If you don't know, check out How to Solder Wires Together .

steps.title: Take a 9V battery clip buckle.
steps.content: Take a 9V battery clip buckle. Notice that there are two wires attached red (+) and black (-). These wires are tied to the DC motor that is supplying power.

steps.title: Take two ends of the same wire either red or black and try to tie a small knot.
steps.content: Take two ends of the same wire either red or black and try to tie a small knot. Then place a hot soldering iron and melt the solder wire over the knot to permanently connect the two wires.

steps.title: Repeat this process as needed to extend the wire length.
steps.content: Repeat this process as needed to extend the wire length. Remember that you should connect red wires to red wires and black wires to black wires.

steps.title: Connect both of the wires to the motor.
steps.content: Connect both of the wires to the motor. Take the end of the red wire and solder it to the top hole of the motor (positive eyebolt). Repeat this process for the black wire, soldering it to the bottom hole (negative eyebolt).

steps.title: Test it.
steps.content: Test it. Snap the clip buckle at the end of the wires to the 9V battery. If everything is done correctly, the shaft will spin clockwise making the car move forward. Note: On the clip buckle, the smaller terminal is positive and the larger terminal is negative. When attaching the larger negative terminal of the clip buckle to the smaller positive terminal of the 9V battery and vice versa, the shaft spins clockwise, causing the car to move forward. Likewise, when placing the larger negative terminal of the clip buckle close to the larger negative terminal of the 9V battery, the shaft spins counter clockwise, causing the car to move backward.

steps.title: Drive it forward.
steps.content: Drive it forward. Attach the larger negative terminal of the clip buckle to the smaller positive terminal of the 9V battery and vice versa. This will enable the car to move forward.

steps.title: Drive it backward.
steps.content: Drive it backward. Place the larger negative terminals and smaller positive terminals of the clip buckle and the 9V battery on top of each other. This will enable the car to move backward.
